title: Is it legal to use copyrighted music? - Quora

response.answer_text: Ask permission, or… Fair use. I love this doctrine, and I’m grateful there is one, because that way a lot of good content exist. Fair use is a doctrine where you can use copyrighted work, just not all of them, so that people who want to enjoy the work would rather go to the legal sites to watch ‘em. There are several rules when implementing fair use: Use copyrighted content in a way that pure enjoyers won’t enjoy. This means changing or altering the work, by, let’s say, making a parody, or like lots have done, making critical comments as a character say something, let’s say. The commentary must be critical that people who just want to enjoy the copyrighted content won’t find their home at your work.Use work less than needed. If it is a video, cut unneeded parts. If its a photo, make it low-res, but not too low-res, ofc. If it is a painting, don’t stabilize the camera; rather move it around. Note, works that have lasted for the owner’s life plus 70 years means that the copyright expired and it is in the public domain; you are free to ignore copyright if that’s the case. Works not made by humans (i.e. this painting by a chimpanzee).Only use when needed. Seriously, don’t get to useless. Don’t play copyrighted music throughout your video without context and without mandate. There are tons of public domain and Creative Commons works, you can use them instead if able.That’s just what you need to know about fair use. If you wanna dive into it all—the history blablabla, you can go to this Wikipedia page that I’ve revised before answering this.

It is not legal to do so without permission. In fact, the U.S. perspective for music and audio tracks is much more restrictive than it is for other content. Fair use is a means to use parts of someone’s work in your own effort (providing you fit the four rules), but courts have judged that music is not applicable when used as samples. And no audio recording is in the public domain; none of them. This is due to a quirk in copyright duration for audio recordings that will resolve itself in another couple of decades. (Although I realize this is off topic.) When someone asks such a broad question like this one, I wonder if they understand what copyright even is: What is the point of copyright? If something is copyright protected, no one can use it at all. The owner has the exclusive right to copy or distribute it. They may give or sell licenses that allow users to use it with their permission. And, in very narrow cases, you can write an article or make a new segment that is about that work, including a sample of that work under fair use. But no, you can’t just use someone’s property without permission.
